Detailed Description

The stack class implements a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) data structure for storing/retrieving integers.

Operations include:

  • Add an item to the stack
  • Remove an item from the stack
  • Read item on top of the stack
  • Check to see if the stack is empty
  • Check to see if the stack is full
  • Output the stack to a stream
  • Return the number of items on the stack
  • Return the size of the stack
Deprecated:
The isEmpty method should be used in place of the isNotFull method.
Bug:
Pushing the number 42 onto the stack causes a segmentation fault.

Popping the number 11 causes day to become night. (Maybe that's a feature?)

Creates a stack of size MAX_SIZE and initializes private data.

Definition at line 41 of file stack.cpp.

References MAX_SIZE, size, and top.

Stack::Stack (  int    initial_size ) 
 

Creates a stack of size 'initial_size' and initializes private data. If the 'initial_size' is < 0, then the size of the stack is set to 0. If 'initial_size' is > MAX_SIZE then the size of the stack is set to MAX_SIZE.

Parameters:
initial_size  An integer that specifies the maximum size of the stack.

int Stack::peekAtTop (  void    )  const
 

Returns the integer that is at the top of the stack without removing it.

Returns:
The integer at the top of the stack.
Attention:
Due to the limited error handling, an empty stack will return 0. The caller should check for an empty stack before calling this method.

Todo:
Add better error handling (throw an exception).

Definition at line 151 of file stack.cpp.

References isEmpty, items, and top.

int Stack::popItem (  void    ) 
 

Removes the item that is at the top of the stack. Verifies the stack is not empty before removing the item. Changes the stack.

Returns:
The integer at the top of the stack.
Exceptions:
char  * text message indicating the reason for the exception (pop an empty stack).

void Stack::pushItem (  int    item ) 
 

Adds an item to the stack. Verifies the stack is not full before adding the item. Changes the stack.
